In addition , the judgment of ORG delivered on DATE is relevant to the present case . In that judgment , the aforementioned court rejected a claim under LAW concerning damage allegedly sustained due to inadequate living conditions in Dob Prison . The claim was lodged by a prisoner who was held in FAC in a cell of QUANTITY together with CARDINAL inmates . The court , which also heard a number of witnesses from the prison , found as established that the claimant , apart from his cell and the lavatories , also had access to the TV room and hallway during DATE , TIME It also found that chairs and tables were situated in the hallway and that CARDINAL of the prison population was working TIME a day , which reduced the number of those who stayed in the cells during that time . The court acknowledged that the situation as regards overcrowding ( number of inmates held in the cells ) was in breach of the domestic regulation providing that CARDINAL prisoners should be held in one cell , and found that the ORG , by virtue of paragraph CARDINAL of section CARDINAL of LAW , would be responsible to prisoners for any damage sustained on that account . However , the court , referring to , inter alia , PERSON v. GPE , no . CARDINAL , DATE , concluded that the situation , though difficult , was not such as to violate the claimant ’s personal rights . No legally recognized damage had therefore been sustained by the claimant . The court also assessed the claimant ’s allegations concerning sanitary conditions , access to the telephone , nutrition and cohabitation with persons affected by transmissible diseases . These aspects of the prison ’s conditions were found not to be in breach of the law .

ORG upheld the above judgment on DATE . It found that the claimant ’s claim contained allegations of torture and breach of one ’s right to dignity . It endorsed the lower court ’s legal qualification and factual findings . ORG also referred to the ORG ’s report of DATE , which , in its opinion , did not point to serious violations . Acknowledging that the situation was not perfect and could cause discomfort to the claimant , ORG concluded that , in the aggregate , the conditions did not amount to undignified treatment or torture .
